climbs.name: Alley Ouff
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Kate Trecartin, June 2109

content.description:
Nice face climbing, a couple of short off widths stacked on top of each other and a short finger crack. This route has a lot of variety.  If your off width technique is good this shouldn't pose a problem as the crux is not that long. A number 5 cam protects the offwidth quite well. 

Climb any route at L Shape or the Gallery to get to the Alley. Near the middle of the Alley, below the crack of Ragged Edges you will see a bolt on a face. The route starts below and left of the bolt. There is no need to stick clip the bolt as there is a bomber nut placement right off the ground. After clipping the bolt move up and slightly right to gain cool cracks and features that lead to the top of the face and a ledge. This is where the off width starts. 
One bolt, chain anchor on a tree. Rap the route.

Climb the crack system to a ledge with a large tree. Step left and climb a corner which leads to a beautiful wide-hands crack. Up this crack to another ledge and tree anchor.

Starts near the right end of the large tree terrace, just left of Rhythm Stick
Standard rack. Save a BD #3 for the crack at the top. Tree anchor

Start as for Anonymous Crack but at the large ledge with a tree, stay right of the tree and continue straight up a crack system past a couple wobbly blocks. Tricky section as the crack gets thin before topping out on the final ledge.



Starts in the crack system left of Rhythm Stick.

Standard rack. Some finger sized and smaller cams for the top section. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Banana Crack
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Caleb Mazurkiewicz, May 2021

content.description:
Get your belayer to anchor in to the big Spruce tree before you take off. There is good gear the whole way but it is challenging to place and find the sweetspots. Climb the initial splitter crack to a ledge. Move straight up then slightly right through and overhang. After pulling up onto a face continue to a ledge then finish on Blueberry. 



Walk along the far left end of the Alley, passing the obvious corner crack/roof for Blueberry. Scramble up the gully passing underneath a flaring chimney until you reach a nice splitter crack just right of a big Spruce. 

Single rack to #1 camalot. A .4 camalot or yellow alien is very valuable on this route.

climbs.name: Blueberry
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Mike Parker, Lucas Toron and Kristy McClellan

content.description:
Climb up the corner then traverse left under the roof on good holds and excellent gear. A #4 Camalot is nice but not essential here. Exit left up a big corner crack that leads to a long ledge. Traverse left across the ledge to a beautiful flaring chimney. Ascend the chimney to another ledge step right then up easier ground to the top. A long pitch with much to offer and great gear throughout.

Located near the far left end of the Alley. This route starts just left of White Shirt Girl under a roof in a corner crack.
Single rack to a 4" piece. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: DDT
climbs.fa: F. Bérubé, C. Goodman, J. Corey 2009

content.description:
Climb up off the narrow ledge into a vertical crack. At its top step right onto the arete past a few bolts. Continue up ledges to the right side of the totem block. Topping out on the block has gotten harder since the removal of a loose rock which used to be on that ledge.

At the right end of the terrace, just as the terrace drops off into L-Shape, there is a bolted anchor. This routes starts in a vertical crack a few feet to the right. To get there, traverse a few feet right on the narrow ledge to gain the crack. Alternatively you can approach from the anchor of Astroboy Direct. From that anchor, step up on the narrow ledge and follow it left until you get to the crack.
Small gear for the initial crack and then 6 bolts protect the rest of the route.

climbs.name: End of The Line
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Caleb Mazurkiewicz, May 2021

content.description:
Climb the sharp corner to a roof. Stay on the natural path to a ledge and finish up and easier slab to the top.



This is the last route in the Alley found on the far left end. You will have to scramble up the gulley passing Blueberry and Banana Crack before getting to the route. The start is in line with a mature Spruce tree about 2 feet away from the wal. 


Single rack to #3 camalot, tree anchor, rap the route.

climbs.name: Kapow!
climbs.fa: F. Berube, D. Caron, M. Harnois 2012

content.description:
From the Astroboy anchor, climb straight up a vertical crack. Pull onto a slab then move up and left to the base of a beautiful crack system. Follow these cracks to a large tree with tat.

This route starts from the anchor at the top of Astroboy Direct.
Standard Rack. Tree anchor

Climb Rhythm Stick to the ledge. From the ledge, follow bolts and gear up the arete of the totem block. 
Fun, funky moves and blind holds would make an onsight very difficult.

right end of the Alley. start up Rhythm Stick
Standard rack. 3 bolts

climbs.name: Ragged Edge
climbs.fa: J. Holmes, G. Hull, A. Gilchrist

content.description:
A few starts are possible. Until recently most would scramble uphill to where the ledge meets the ground, then traverse right along the ledge, past the large tree to get to the crack. It is now possible to climb straight up the wall directly below the crack although this is probably harder than 5.9 but a slight run out is protected by a new bolt.

Look partway up the wall to locate a small ledge with a very large tree growing out of it. This route climbs the cracks to the right of the tree.
standard rack

climbs.name: Rhythm Stick
climbs.fa: J. Holmes, G. Hull, A. Gilchrist

content.description:
Climb the crack system past a wobbly block and into a v-slot. From the ledge above the slot, make your way behind the totem block and climb to its top. Enjoy the view!

Route begins on the right end of the Alley. There is a bolted anchor on the right edge of the wall where it drops off into L-Shape but it's a lot more comfortable to belay from a few feet left (uphill).
Standard rack. Tree anchor

From Astroboy Anchors traverse left on the narrow ledge to gain an easy vertical crack leading to a small ledge in a corner. (From the terrace traverse right to the same crack). Continue up the corner to some ledges. Trend left at the end to finish on the tree with tat above the totem block.

starts off the narrow ledge to the right of the terrace. Belay either from the right side of the terrace or from the Astroboy Direct anchor.
standard rack

Crux is up high getting up into a corner crack. This is a fantastic route with great movement, features and gear throughout.

This route is located in the upper left side of The Alley. The start for the new variation (yellow line) is impossible to miss. Look for a blocky roof and left facing corner. Climb up the corner to the roof then move right onto the face. After getting on the face move up a series of cracks and ledges to the top. The original start is 10 feet right on a narrow ledge. This start is also good but quite intimidating and difficult to protect.
Single rack to 4" piece. The 4 is not absolutely essential but is very nice to have. Bring long runners to extend pro under the roof. Tree anchor.

The Alley is a very secluded wall tucked away above the Gallery Wall (L-Shape). The climbing here is on generally high quality grey granite. All routes on this wall are excellent ranging from the classic Rhythm Sticks to stellar jamming of Ragged Edges. With the number of routes available you could easily spend an afternoon here. Take a summit pack with a lunch and some water if you want to take you time to climb all of these routes. If this wall were on the ground it would likely be the most popular wall at Cochrane Lane.
